hook.text: In Bangladesh, wells drilled to avoid surface contamination tapped into arsenic-laced rock.

buildup.text: Millions drank arsenic-contaminated water for years before anyone tested for it.

discovery.text: Chronic arsenic exposure causes cancers, skin lesions, and organ damage over decades.

twist.text: The wells were funded by aid organizations trying to prevent waterborne disease â€” an unintended tragedy.

climax.text: Simple, cheap filters can remove arsenic, but distribution to 100 million at-risk people is slow.

punchline.text: The cure for one water problem accidentally created another.

quiz.question: Why did Bangladesh's wells contain arsenic?
options: They tapped into naturally arsenic-rich rock
